frame.name: Spatial_contact
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> is located in contact with a <fen>Ground</fen>. With some words that evoke this frame, the <fen>Figure</fen> is also asserted to be fully or partially supported by the <fen>Ground</fen> (e.g. <m>on</m>), while in others a support relation is either denied (e.g. <m>to</m>, as in "she put her hand <m>to</m> the wall") or unspecified (e.g. <m>against</m>). In addition, some LUs assert a direction in which to find the <fen>Figure</fen> from the <fen>Ground</fen> (e.g. <m>atop</m>).
<ex>There <ment>was</ment> <fex name="Figure">a tight-fitting lid</fex> <t>on</t> <fex name="Ground">the bottle</fex> .</ex> <ex><t>Against</t> <fex name="Ground">the back wall</fex> <m>stood</m> <fex name="Figure">a young black man</fex> staring at his shoes .</ex> <ex><t>Against</t> <fex name="Ground">the back wall</fex> <fex name="Figure">three students were reading</fex> .</ex> <ex>Clean if <fex name="Figure">the jewelery</fex> <m>is</m> ever <m>in</m> <t>contact</t> <fex name="Ground">with water or chlorine</fex> .</ex>
This frame participates in productive metaphor cases, like "shining a light on corruption", "Stalin's hand lay heavy on the presses", "it touched her heart" in each of which an abstract entity affects another entity as if they were in physical contact. <ex></ex>
This frame is intended to cover the description of writing, images, or situations being depicted on a document, canvas, screen, or other flat surface, including metaphorical cases where there is no literal document, like "on record" or "pretty low on my list". <ex><fex name="Figure">They were arguing</fex> <t>on</t> <fex name="Ground">screen</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">Watching chess</fex> is pretty low <t>on</t> <fex name="Ground">my list</fex> .</ex>
The use of on.prep to describe use of a vehicle is not included in this frame even though it does involve contact and support. The sense distinction is proven by the omissability of the Ground only in the vehicle cases: <ex>She is already on (the bus/the ship...) .</ex> <ex>My paper is on *(the desk) .</ex> This use is related to Ride_vehicle. A similar argument holds for uses of on.prep with a clothing Figure, which virtually always omits the Ground; see Wearing. <ex></ex>
The use of on.prep and upon.prep for Topics is considered a non-productive metaphor (see Topic). No other target in the frame allows the use, nor is is correlated with other language of the source domain of contact (e.g. stand, sit, lie, put, rest). </def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex>The cat is <t>on</t> <fex name="Grnd">the mat</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
<ex><fex name="Fig">The cat</fex> is <t>on</t> the mat.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition: <def-root>An indication of how accessible the <fen>Figure</fen> is to some participant in the speech context (either the speaker or the addressee, or some other highly salient viewpoint in a narrative). This FE normally describes availability for manipulation and use, but may simply describe how easily seen or difficult to see the <fen>Figure</fen> is. There is a closed class of items that can fill this slot, including only 'right' indicating ease of access, and 'way', 'all the way', or (dialectally) 'clear' indicating distance and difficulty of access. <ex>My bag sat <fex name="Accessibility">right</fex> <t>on</t> the table.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>. This FE is filled by one of a closed class of adverbs: up, down, out (meaning 'beyond the boundary around the viewpoint'), back (meaning 'along a line from front to back of landmark, and relatively inaccessible'), and, more rarely, away, along, and dialectally, back down (meaning 'down and behind').
<ex>The cat is <fex name="Dir">up</fex> <t>on top</t> of the table .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
<ex>He was <t>against</t> the wall <fex name="tim">on Friday</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figures
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of each other.</def-root>

FE.name: Deixis
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how the locative phrase relates to the grounding of the speech situation, either locating it near (here) or far (there, yonder), or specifically separated from the speech context by distance or a barrier (over). Fillers of this FE are restricted to this closed class of items.
<ex>It is lying <fex name="Deixis">here</fex> <t>on</t> my desk .</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, directly, and due (and some combinations of these), but also occurs with rarer items like 'smack dab'.
<ex>I stood <fex name="Directness">right</fex> <t>on</t> the edge .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Temporal_profile
FE.definition:
<def-root>A description of how the access path to the <fen>Ground</fen> interacts with time. This FE is filled only by the closed class adverbial back.adv (which indicates that the position was occupied by the <fen>Figure</fen> before). While this FE in its most basic use refers to cases of actual motion, it can be used with descriptions of static position, where motion is backgrounded.
<ex>Put the book <fex name="Temporal_profile">back</fex> <t>upon</t> the shelf.</ex> </def-root>

lexUnit.name: on.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in contact with and supported by.

lexUnit.name: atop.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: in contact with the upper part of and supported by.

lexUnit.name: on top (of).prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: supported and in contact with the upper surface.

lexUnit.name: against.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: touching in such a way that pressure is exerted.

lexUnit.name: touch.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: be positioned such that surfaces are in contact.

lexUnit.name: contact.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: be positioned so that there is no separation between surfaces.

lexUnit.name: contact.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the state of having no separation (between two or more surfaces).

lexUnit.name: tangent.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: (usually of a geometrical line) touching in only one place.

lexUnit.name: upon.prep
lexUnit.definition: FN: touching and at least partially supported by.
